abstractText: Abstract. The coefficients of the stochastic differential equations with Markovian switching (SDEwMS) additionally depend on a Markov chain and there is no notion of differentiating such functions with respect to the Markov chain. In particular, this implies that the ItôTaylor expansion for SDEwMS is not a straightforward extension of the Itô-Taylor expansion for stochastic differential equations (SDEs). Further, higher-order numerical schemes for SDEwMS are not available in the literature, perhaps because of the absence of the Itô-Taylor expansion. In this article, first, we overcome these challenges and derive the Itô-Taylor expansion for SDEwMS, under some suitable regularity assumptions on the coefficients, by developing new techniques. Secondly, we demonstrate an application of our first result on the Itô-Taylor expansion in the numerical approximations of SDEwMS. We derive an explicit scheme for SDEwMS using the Itô-Taylor expansion and show that the strong rate of convergence of our scheme is equal to γ ∈ {n/2 : n ∈ N} under some suitable Lipschitz-type conditions on the coefficients and their derivatives. It is worth mentioning that designing and analysis of the Itô-Taylor expansion and the γ ∈ {n/2 : n ∈ N}-order scheme for SDEwMS become much more complex and involved due to the entangling of continuous dynamics and discrete events. Finally, our results coincide with the corresponding results on SDEs when the state of the Markov chain is a singleton set.

1. Introduction
The stochastic differential equations with Markovian switching (SDEwMS) are widely used in many real-life situations, see, for example, [1], [6], [10], [11], [13], [14] and the references therein. The existence and uniqueness of the solution of SDEwMS are well-known in the literature, see [2] and [6]. However, the explicit solutions of such equations are often unknown, which makes the numerical approximations of SDEwMS an important subject of investigation. The numerical schemes of order 0.5 for SDEwMS, namely the Euler scheme, tamed Euler scheme and implicit Euler scheme, have received significant attention in the literature, see [6], [9], [2] and [8]. Recently, order 1.0 schemes such as (tamed) explicit Milstein-type scheme for SDEwMS and their strong rate of convergence have been studied in [4], [5] and [7]. However, no attention is given to the investigation of the higher-order numerical schemes for SDEwMS, perhaps because of the non-availability of the Itô-Taylor expansion for functions depending on a Markov chain. The derivation of the Itô-Taylor expansion for SDEwMS is not a straightforward extension of the corresponding results on SDEs (see [3]), mainly because the coefficients of SDEwMS depend additionally on a Markov chain and there is no notion of derivative of a Markov chain dependent function with respect to the Markov chain.
In this article, we present novel strategies to address these challenges to derive and demonstrate the Itô-Taylor expansion for SDEwMS. More precisely, in the derivation of the Itô-Taylor expansion for the traditional SDEs, as discussed in [3], authors deal with two types of integrals, namely, Riemann integral and Itô’s integral. However, to derive the Itô-Taylor expansion for SDEwMS, we have to deal with one more form of integral, which is the integral with respect to the optional process {[Mi0k0 ](t) : t ∈ [0, T ]} (see Subsection 2.1) associated with the Markov chain. Thus, the techniques developed for SDEs in [3] can not be extended in a straightforward manner to SDEwMS, which necessitates the development of novel strategies. Indeed, multiindices, multiple integrals, hierarchical and remainder sets are defined by taking into consideration the new integrals with respect to {[Mi0k0 ](t) : t ∈ [0, T ]} which brings additional complexity in the derivation and proofs of the main results on the Itô-Taylor expansion and the explicit γ ∈ {n/2 : n ∈ N}-order scheme for SDEwMS. Here, it is worth mentioning that designing and
analysis become difficult because of the random switching of the Markov chain and entangling of the continuous dynamics of the state and discrete events arising due to switching of the Markov chain. Further, if the state space of the Markov chain is a singleton set, then SDEwMS become SDEs. In such a case, our Itô-Taylor expansion reduces to the classical Itô-Taylor expansion for SDEs given in [3]. We provide an application of the Itô-Taylor expansion in the derivation of higher-order numerical schemes for SDEwMS. We show that the strong rate of convergence of the general numerical scheme for SDEwMS is γ ∈ {n/2 : n ∈ N}. For a Markov chain with singleton state space, i.e., when SDEwMS reduce to SDEs, our γ ∈ {n/2 : n ∈ N}-order scheme is the same as the γ ∈ {n/2 : n ∈ N}-order scheme discussed in [3]. In this case, the regularity requirement on the coefficients is much weaker in our setting when compared with the correspodning results for SDEs given in [3].
The paper is organized as follows. The formulation and preliminaries of the article are given in Section 2. In Section 3, notations and definitions are given, which are used throughout the paper. In Section 4, the main results on the Itô-Taylor expansion and its application in γ ∈ {n/2 : n ∈ N}-order numerical schemes for SDEwMS are stated. The technical lemmas required to prove the Itô-Taylor expansion for SDEwMS, including the proof of the Itô-Taylor expansion, are given in Section 5. In the last section, we explain the derivation of the γ ∈ {n/2 : n ∈ N}order numerical scheme and establish its moment stability and the strong rate of convergence.

3. Notations and definitions
For sets A and B, define A \ B := {x : x ∈ A and x /∈ B}, A ∩ B := {x : x ∈ A, x ∈ B} and A ∪ B := {x : x ∈ A or x ∈ B}. A(i,j) and A(j) stand for the (i, j)-th element and the j-th column of a matrix A respectively and the k-th element of a vector v is denoted by vk. xy denotes the inner product of vectors x and y. The indicator function of a set A is denoted by 1A. ϕ stands for an empty set and by convention, the sum over an empty set is taken to be zero. N (s,t] is the no. of jump and τ1, . . . , τN(s,t] are the jump times of the Markov chain α in the interval (s, t] for any s < t ∈ [0, T ]. The general constant is denoted by C which can vary from place to place and does not depend on the step-size.
3.1. Multi-indices. We call a row vector β = (j1, . . . , jl), a multi-index of length l(β) = l ∈ N, when ji ∈ {N1, . . . , Nµ, N̄µ, 0, 1, . . . ,m} for all i ∈ {1, . . . , l} and satisfies the following condition,
(a) if ji ∈ {N1, . . . , Nµ, N̄µ}, then ji−1 /∈ {N1, . . . , Nµ, N̄µ} for all i ∈ {2, . . . , l}
where µ ∈ N is fixed. Here, Ni signifies the number i and N̄i, the number i+1 for any i ∈ N. A multi-index β of length zero is denoted by ν, i.e., l(ν) = 0. Here, each component of multi-index β represents a type of integral in multiple integrals which becomes more clear when we define multiple integrals in Subsection 3.3. Furthermore, the positive integer µ is related to the strong rate γ ∈ {n/2, n ∈ N} of convergence of the numerical schemes considered in this paper (see Subsection 4.2).
Also, assume that M := {β : l(β) ∈ N ∪ {0}} denotes the set of all multi-indices of arbitrary length. We divide the set M of all multi-indices into disjoint sets M1, M2 and M3 as follows,
M1 := {(j1, . . . , jl) ∈ M : ji ∈ {0, 1, . . . ,m}∀ i ∈ {1, . . . , l}} ∪ {ν}, M2 := {(j1, . . . , jl) ∈ M \M1 : j1 ∈ {0, 1, . . . ,m}}, M3 := {(j1, . . . , jl) ∈ M \M1 : j1 ∈ {N1, . . . , Nµ, N̄µ}}.
For any β = (j1, . . . , jl) ∈ M \ {ν}, the deletion of its first component is represented by −β = (j2, . . . , jl) and the deletion of its last component is represented by β− = (j1, . . . , jl−1). Notice that −β = β− = ν for any β ∈ M of length l(β) = 1.
For β = (j1, . . . , jk), β̄ = (j̄1, . . . , j̄l) ∈ M, the concatenation operation ⋆ is defined by
β ⋆ β̄ := (j1, . . . , jk, j̄1, . . . , j̄l) ∈ M with ν ⋆ β̄ = β̄ and β ⋆ ν = β.
Also, for β = (j1, . . . , jl) ∈ M,
n(β) : number of components of β which are equal to k where k ∈ {1, . . . ,m}, n̄(β) : number of components of β which are equal to 0, [n](β) : number of components of β which are equal to k where k ∈ {N1, . . . , Nµ, N̄µ},
η(β) = n(β) + 2n̄(β) + µmax(β) where µmax(β) = max i∈{1,...,l} {ji: ji ∈ {N1, . . . , Nµ, N̄µ} for any i ∈ {1, . . . , l}}. Clearly, η(ν) = 0.
Notice that η(β) may be equal for two different β ∈ M whose length is not same. For example, η((1, N1)) = η((N1, 1, N1)) = 2. Further, {β ∈ M : η(β) < 0} is an empty set.
Example 1. Let m = 4 and consider a multi-index β = (0, N2, 2, 1, N3, 0) of length 6. Clearly, β satisfies conditions (a) mentioned above. Then, −β = (N2, 2, 1, N3, 0) and β− = (0, N2, 2, 1, N3). β ⋆ β̄ = (0, N2, 2, 1, N3, 0, 4, 0, 0, N3 , 1, N̄1) ∈ M.
Clearly, β ⋆ β̄ satisfies conditions (a) and is a multi-index of length 12.

Remark 1. When the state space S of the Markov chain α is a singleton set, then the SDEwMS (2.1) reduces to an SDE and the integrals corresponding to the components {N1, . . . , Nµ, N̄µ} in the multiple integrals vanish. In such a situation, the multi-indices and multiple integrals defined above reduce to the case as discussed in Section 5.2 of [3]. The components {N1, . . . , Nµ, N̄µ} in multi-indices and the corresponding multiple integrals appear due to the switching of the Markov chain.

3.4. Hierarchical and remainder sets. A subset A of M is called a hierarchical set if sup β∈A l(β) < ∞ and −β ∈ A for every β ∈ A \ {ν}.
The remainder set B(A) corresponding to a hierarchical set A is define as,
B(A) := {β ∈ M \A : −β ∈ A}.
If A = ϕ, then B(A) = {ν}.
Example 4. Let A := {β ∈ M : η(β) ≤ 2} with µ = 3. Then
A = {ν, (N1), (N2), (0), (k), (k,N1), (N1, k), (k1, k), (N1, k,N1); k, k1 ∈ {1, . . . ,m}}
is the hierarchical set and corresponding remainder set is
B(A) = {(N3), (N̄3), (0, N1), (0, N2), (k,N2), (N1, 0), (N2, 0), (N3, 0), (N̄3, 0), (0, 0), (k, 0), (N2 , k),

4. Main results
In this section, we introduce two key findings of this paper, namely, the Itô-Taylor expansion for functions additionally depending on the Markov chain α (see Subsection 4.1) and the explicit numerical scheme of arbitrary order γ ∈ {n/2 : n ∈ N} for SDEwMS (2.1) (see Subsection 4.2).
4.1. Itô-Taylor expansion. In the Itô-Taylor expansion, the regularity of the drift coefficient b of SDEwMS (2.1) is identified with the help of following notations.
Db := {β ∈ M : β ⋆ (0) ⋆ β̄ ∈ A ∪ B(A), the components of β̄ ∈ M are not equal to 0}, Kb := max β∈Db {n(β) + 2n̄(β)},
and for the regularity of the diffusion coefficient σ, we define,
Dσ = {β ∈ M : β ⋆ (j) ⋆ β̄ ∈ A ∪ B(A), j ∈ {0, 1, . . . ,m}, the components of β̄ ∈ M are not equal to k where k ∈ {0, 1, . . . ,m}}, Kσ := max β∈Dσ {n(β) + 2n̄(β)}.
Similarly, for the regularity of the function f , we define,
Kf := max β∈A∪B(A) {n(β) + 2n̄(β)}.
Moreover, we write the hierarchical set A as A = Ã ∪ (A \ Ã) where
Ã := {(j1, . . . , jl) ∈ A : ji ∈ {N1, . . . , Nµ, N̄µ} for any i ∈ {1, . . . , l}}.
We make the following assumption on the coefficients of SDEwMS (2.1).
Assumption 3. For a hierarchical set A and for any i0 ∈ S, k ∈ {1, . . . , d} and j ∈ {1, . . . ,m}, let bk(·, i0) and σ (k,j)(·, i0) be Kb− and Kσ− times continuously differentiable functions respectively.
The following theorem is the first main result of this article which is proved in Section 5.
Theorem 2 (Itô-Taylor expansion). For a hierarchical set A, let Assumption 3 be satisfied and assume that f : Rd × S 7→ R is a Kf−times continuously differentiable function. Then, for all s < t ∈ [0, T ],
f(X(t), α(t)) = ∑

almost surely, provided all the multiple integrals appearing above exist.
The above expansion is characterized by the specific selection of the hierarchical set A. Later in Subsection 6.1, it is used to construct the numerical scheme of arbitrary order γ ∈ {n/2 : n ∈ N}, see equation (4.1).
Remark 2. The aforementioned expansion can be considered as a generalization of the ItôTaylor expansion for SDE discussed in Theorem 5.5.1 of [3] in the sense that the coefficients of
SDE additionally depend on a Markov chain. Indeed, if the state space S of the Markov chain α is a singleton set, then SDEwMS (2.1) reduces to an SDE and Ã = ϕ which leads to the Itô-Taylor expansion for SDE. The terms corresponding to Ã in the above expansion appear due to the presence of the Markov chain in the coefficients of the SDE.

4.2. Explicit γ-order numerical scheme. For explicit numerical scheme of γ ∈ {n/2 : n ∈ N}-order (see equation (4.1)), we fix µ = 2γ and define
Abγ := {ν} ∪ {(j1, . . . , jl) ∈ M : η((j1, . . . , jl)) ≤ 2γ − 1, if ji = 0∀ i ∈ {1, . . . , l}} ∪ {(j1, . . . , jl) ∈ M : η((j1, . . . , jl)) ≤ 2γ − 2 if ji ∈ {N1, . . . , Nµ, 1, . . . ,m} for any i ∈ {1, . . . , l}}. Aσγ := {β ∈ M : η(β) ≤ 2γ − 1}.
The sets Abγ and A σ γ are hierarchical sets and their remainder sets are denoted by B(A b γ) := {β ∈ M \ Abγ : −β ∈ A b γ} and B(A σ γ) := {β ∈ M \ A σ γ : −β ∈ A σ γ}, respectively. Further, we write Abγ = Ã b γ ∪ (A b γ \ Ã b γ) and A σ γ = Ã σ γ ∪ (A σ γ \ Ã σ γ) where
Ãbγ := {(j1, . . . , jl) ∈ A b γ : ji ∈ {N1, . . . , Nµ} for any i ∈ {1, . . . , l}}, Ãσγ := {(j1, . . . , jl) ∈ A σ γ : ji ∈ {N1, . . . , Nµ} for any i ∈ {1, . . . , l}}.
Also, we assume that bk(·, i0) and σ (k,j)(·, i0) are sufficiently smooth functions for all i0 ∈ S, k ∈ {1, . . . , d} and j ∈ {1, . . . ,m}. We partition the interval [0, T ] into nT ∈ N sub-intervals of equal length h = T/nT > 0, i.e., tn = nh for any n ∈ {0, 1, . . . , nT }. Remark 3. If the state space S of the Markov chain α is a singleton set, then the SDEwMS (2.1) reduces to an SDE and the integrals appearing in the terms corresponding to the sets Ãbγ and Ãσγ in equation (4.1) vanish. In this case, (4.1) is the the γ-order explicit numerical scheme for SDE, see Section 10.6 in [3]. Clearly, terms corresponding to the sets Ãbγ and Ã σ γ in (4.1) appear due to the presence of the Markov chain.

Remark 10. If there is no jump then ζ̃, B̄2, B̄3, ˜̄B2, ˜̄B3, B̄4, ˜̄B4 in preceding proof are empty sets and SDEwMS (2.1) reduces to an SDE. As a result, by repeating the preceding steps, we can prove Theorem 5.5.1 of [3], i.e., Itô-Taylor expansion for SDE.
6. Explicit γ-order scheme for SDEwMS
This section is devoted to the derivation of the γ ∈ {n/2 : n ∈ N}-order numerical scheme for
SDEwMS (2.1) and prove its moment stability and strong rate of convergence.

Now, we prove Aσγ ⊂ A σ γ−0.5 ∪ B σ 1 ∪ B σ 2 ∪ B σ 3 ∪ B σ 5 . For this, let β ∈ A σ γ \ {ν} which implies η(β) ≤ 2γ − 1. If η(β) ≤ 2γ − 2, then β ∈ Aσγ−0.5. Further, consider η(β) = 2γ − 1 which gives rise to two cases, either η(−β) < η(β) or η(−β) = η(β). If η(−β) < η(β), then by the definition of hierarchical and remainder sets from Subsection 3.4, we have −β ∈ Aσγ−0.5 and β ∈ B(A σ γ−0.5) which gives β ∈ Bσ1 ∪ B σ 2 ∪ B σ 3 . Moreover, if η(−β) = η(β), then −β ∈ B σ 3 and β ∈ B σ 5 . Hence
Aσγ = A σ γ−0.5 ∪ B σ 1 ∪ B σ 2 ∪ B σ 3 ∪ B σ 5 and Ãσγ = Ã σ γ−0.5 ∪ B σ 2 ∪ B σ 3 ∪ B σ 5 .
